briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 4, 2026. Based on the 88 climate-related news items collected today, we will provide an in-depth analysis of domestic and international climate change trends and response efforts.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Perceived Climate Crisis and Urgency
sections.content: Four out of five European citizens are experiencing the impacts of climate change, yet preparedness for heatwaves remains insufficient, demonstrating that the reality of the climate crisis has already deeply infiltrated our daily lives [3]. The Winter Olympics, in particular, are facing increasing difficulties in hosting due to climate change, with demands for the IOC to 'respond better' and even proposals for significant date changes [48, 50, 59, 68, 73, 80]. In the United States, there have been multiple reports recently that cold snaps, combined with human psychology, are being perceived as even more severe [63, 64, 71, 75, 77, 78, 79, 81, 85]. Last January in Australia, intense heatwaves led to the death of over 80% of flying fox colonies, starkly revealing the direct impact on ecosystems [86]. Research indicating that reductions in marine emissions are causing global warming beyond expectations and that climate change is accelerating the destruction of major greenhouse gases [72, 84] once again emphasizes that the climate crisis is not a distant problem but a global phenomenon requiring immediate action [70].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Carbon Neutrality Implementation: Urgent Need for Enhanced Effectiveness
sections.content: Criticism has been raised that the carbon neutrality master plans of domestic local governments are 'failing grades' in terms of effectiveness [10, 12, 21, 45]. Only 11 out of 226 local governments nationwide received an A grade, with the issue being the 'cookie-cutter' approach to planning that fails to adequately reflect local conditions and characteristics [11, 20, 46]. In this regard, Assemblyman Han Jeong-soo emphasized the need to develop tangible carbon neutrality implementation measures [16, 17, 28]. Connecticut also reported falling off track to meet its climate goals despite reducing greenhouse gas emissions, once again highlighting the importance of plan quality and implementation [67]. Furthermore, the 'RE60' policy for public institutions is being criticized as a paradox of buying 'solar energy labels' with taxpayer money, raising questions about its actual carbon reduction effectiveness [42].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Domestic and International Climate Change Response and Adaptation Efforts
sections.content: Various proactive efforts to address climate change have been reported domestically. The National Institute of Ecology discussed strategies for climate change preparedness [1], and Jeollanam-do is actively pursuing the establishment of a Marine and Fisheries Climate Change Response Center, developing related strategies [2, 6, 7]. Daejeon City is strengthening disaster response cooperation [5], and Jeongseon County is exploring adaptation strategies tailored to local characteristics, such as expanding apple cultivation by leveraging climate change as an opportunity [8]. Concrete actions for achieving carbon neutrality are also active: Seoul City is expanding participation in 'Climate-Friendly Buildings' to reduce greenhouse gas emissions [9], and Pohang City has accelerated carbon neutrality through the dissemination of electric vehicles [13]. Various local governments and organizations, including Geoje City, Chungcheongbuk-do, and Gyeongnam Environmental Foundation, are launching carbon neutrality committees or collaborating with private organizations to spread carbon neutrality practices in daily life [14, 18, 19, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27]. In the renewable energy sector, solutions for intermittency were explored at the '2026 Korea Smart Grid Expo' [31], and innovative efforts are continuing both domestically and internationally, such as attempts to transition to next-generation power grids using AI [36, 41] and Haenam County's legislative pre-announcement for a citizen fund ordinance [35] [56, 76].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Perception and Discussion of Climate Change
sections.content: Extensive discussions on climate change are taking place within the international community. Regarding the 2026 Winter Olympics, there are calls for the IOC to 'respond better' to climate change [50], and connections between climate change and various sectors such as transportation and fiduciary duties are being explored [55, 74]. Within the United States, an analysis suggests that understanding of climate change is shaped by skepticism, dogmatism, and personal experience [61]. Meanwhile, the EU is re-evaluating its climate diplomacy strategy after the COP30 summit [88], and India is demonstrating its national commitment to climate change response by including five major climate and energy-related announcements in its 2026 government budget [87]. However, in-depth reflection and debate also continue regarding new technologies, policies, and response strategies, including opinions on whether AI could be the next climate change [52], concerns raised by California's plastic bag transition law regarding climate change [69], and discussions that wetland flooding to combat climate change could be counterproductive [83].

briefing.closing: Through today's briefing, we have examined the urgent reality of climate change, along with the diverse efforts and challenges faced domestically and internationally to overcome it. This is a time that demands sustained attention and concrete action. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: [Exclusive] Carbon Neutrality Master Plans Churned Out Like Cookie-Cutters... Effectiveness Receives 'Failing Grade'
articles.original_title: [ë‹¨ë…]â€˜ë¶•ì–´ë¹µâ€™ì²˜ëŸ¼ ì°ì–´ë‚¸ íƒ„ì†Œì¤‘ë¦½ê¸°ë³¸ê³„íšâ€¦ì‹¤íš¨ì„± â€˜ë‚™ì œì â€™
articles.description: Participants of the '9.27 Climate Justice March' performed a 'die-in' near Cheonggyecheon Stream in Jongno-gu, Seoul last year. Reporter Han Su-bin. An analysis of the Carbon Neutrality Master Plans (Tan Gibon) submitted by local basic governments nationwide, outlining regional greenhouse gas reduction strategies, reveals that many contain 'similar policies' and plans for 'last-minute' reductions to meet deadlines, without adequately reflecting local conditions and characteristics.

summary.phenomenon: On September 27th last year, participants of the Climate Justice March held a 'die-in performance' near Cheonggyecheon Stream in Jongno-gu, Seoul. An analysis of the Carbon Neutrality Master Plans (Tan Gibon) submitted by local basic governments nationwide revealed that they often fail to properly reflect local conditions and characteristics, instead proposing 'last-minute' reduction strategies based on similar, generic policies to meet target deadlines.
summary.outlook: The effectiveness of the Carbon Neutrality Master Plans has been rated as 'failing,' leading to anticipated difficulties in achieving greenhouse gas reduction targets.

articles.title: More than 80% of flying fox colony wiped out as January heatwaves kill thousands of bats

summary.phenomenon: In January last week, an intense heatwave that struck southeastern Australia resulted in the death of over 80% of a colony of approximately 1,000 bats (flying foxes) in Naracoorte, South Australia. Only 180 bats survived, 34 of which are juveniles.
summary.cause: The intense heatwave that affected South Australia in January led to the demise of thousands of bats.
summary.outlook: The 34 surviving juvenile bats are anticipated to require several months for recovery.
